name: Humans
nature_and_culture: Thrive in every climate. Short lifespans drive ambition, invention, and volatility—empires rise and fall within an elf’s lifetime.
combat: Wildly adaptable: disciplined legions, cunning raiders, swashbucklers, arcanists—never the same twice.
spice: Other races say humans burn twice as bright, half as long.
appearance: Humans vary wildly—skin from pale to dark, hair in every common hue, and eyes of brown, blue, green, hazel, or grey. Medium height and build are most common, but stature ranges from slight to imposing. Clothing spans the spectrum: quilted gambesons and leathers for soldiers, loose linens and wool for peasants, silks and velvet for nobles—all shaped by region and fashion.

name: Forest Elves
nature_and_culture: Tree-top cities and living bridges. Revere spirits of the wild and defend groves with quiet zeal.
combat: Stealth archers and guerrillas, vanishing into undergrowth between precise volleys.
spice: Their whispers ride the wind through branches.
appearance: Forest Elves are typically of fair, tanned, or olive complexion with hair of blonde, white, auburn, or light brown. Medium in height and slim yet toned, their sharp eyes and pointed ears lend a watchful grace. Their clothing is leather and pelt worked with leaves and living plants—minimal to moderate coverage for agility, often earth-dyed and silent in motion.

name: Dark Elves
nature_and_culture: Underworld cities and secret covens. Politically ruthless but artistically refined; pragmatists above all.
combat: Poisoners, assassins, and shadow mages; excel at surgical strikes and retreats.
spice: Their eyes glimmer in the dark like a predator’s.
appearance: Dark Elves bear pale, dusky-brown skin offset by hair of grey, brown, black, or silver-white. Tall and curvaceous, their angular features are sharpened by elegant pointed ears and a predatory glimmer to the eyes. They prefer dark leathers and fabrics cut close to the body, embellished with silver fittings and gemstones. Fine silver tattoos often wind across the skin, catching moonlight like constellations.

name: Snow Elves
nature_and_culture: Isolationist keepers of high passes and tundras; winter is both teacher and god.
combat: Endurance fighters using icy terrain to exhaust foes; frost-forged arms.
spice: Breath mists in warmth; stray snowflakes follow their steps.
appearance: Snow Elves have pure white skin and slim, small frames. Hair ranges from white and grey to black with icy blue or purple tones; eyes glint in frosted hues. Their clothing is minimalistic—revealing leather and simple fabrics designed for speed and adapted bodies that thrive in cold. Lines are austere, colors pale, often trimmed with fur only for grip and wind-shear.

name: Great Elves
nature_and_culture: Stewards of ancient citadels and high culture; stern traditionalists with long memories.
combat: Elegant war-mages and champions; discipline married to arcana.
spice: Their lineage carries a faint celestial resonance.
appearance: Great Elves tower over most, their skin glowing in hues of yellow or orange. Hair cascades in blonde, brown, auburn, or pale metallics; eyes gleam gold, silver, or jewel-tones. Their wardrobes favor ornamental robes and ceremonial armor heavy with gold and silver jewelry—vestments that turn battlefield and court into theatre.

name: Iron Dwarves
nature_and_culture: Forge-and-clan traditionalists of deep mountains; worth measured in craft and duty.
combat: Shield walls, hammers, and implacable advance; masters of siege defense.
spice: In battle, their heartbeats echo like hammer blows.
appearance: Iron Dwarves are short and powerfully built, with stone-gray or earthy brown complexions and work-roughened skin. Hair runs black, brown, or red, often braided; beards are clasped with iron and steel. Their attire favors mail, plate, and heavy leathers blackened by forge soot, along with aprons and tool-laden belts.

name: Hill Dwarves
nature_and_culture: Valley farmers, brewers, and caravaners; convivial but stubborn.
combat: Village militias with axes, crossbows, heavy shields; immovable on home ground.
spice: Ale strong enough to floor an orc.
appearance: Broad and ruddy, Hill Dwarves wear their sun with pride. Hair is often sun-bleached blonde or light brown, with thick beards knotted for work. Garb is practical—quilted vests, sturdy boots, homespun shirts—embroidered with clan motifs and beer-stain honesty.

name: Ember Dwarves
nature_and_culture: Volcanic-hall smith-kings; clans compete to forge legends; fire revered as divine.
combat: Molten blades, warhammers, and fire magic; aggressive shock smiths.
spice: Skin radiates heat, scorching parchment if held too long.
appearance: Ember Dwarves carry soot-darkened skin and ember-glowing eyes. Hair is red or coal-black and often singed at the tips. Their armor is blackened steel, brass, and obsidian plates over fireproof leathers, with vents and grills like tiny furnaces.

name: Coastal Dwarves
nature_and_culture: Cliff citadels and sea-caves; bold traders and shipwrights, distrusted by mountain kin.
combat: Harpoons, nets, boarding axes; ruthless in close-quarters fights on deck.
spice: Creed: “Stone sinks, ships sail.”
appearance: Weathered and sea-tough, Coastal Dwarves wear tanned skin and salt-crusted beards braided with shells. Hair runs sea-bleached white to blonde. Their clothes are tarred leathers, canvas coats, and rope belts—made for decks slick with brine.

name: Ashfoot Orcs
nature_and_culture: Volcanic clans treating fire as sacred; ash-painted shamans and obsidian charms.
combat: Brutal close-combat with obsidian and steel; barefoot coal-walkers.
spice: War drums packed with volcanic stones rumble like quakes.
appearance: Tall and scarred, Ashfoot Orcs wear gray-black skin like cooled ash. Ember-lit eyes glare above obsidian charms. They favor dark leather harnesses, ash-daubed skin, and rugged kilts, leaving feet bare to walk on coals during rites.

name: Storm Orcs
nature_and_culture: Coast raiders who test souls in thunder; coming-of-age beneath lightning-clawed skies.
combat: Thunderous charges and storm-touched magic; fearless boarding and cliff assaults.
spice: Air around them smells of ozone; static crackles when enraged.
appearance: Broad and tall, Storm Orcs bear storm-gray or sea-green skin. Hair is often braided and wind-tangled, sometimes charred at the ends. They wear sea-leathers, harnesses, and mail scavenged from boarding raids, hung with hooks and knots that sing in the wind.

name: Mountain Orcs
nature_and_culture: Crag fortresses, goat herds, and echoing chants across ridgelines.
combat: High-ground ambushers triggering rockfalls before charging.
spice: War-cries carry for miles, rolling like thunder.
appearance: Stocky and slate-skinned, Mountain Orcs are built for altitude and cold. Their garb is layered furs, rock-dyed cloth, and strapped plate scavenged from fallen foes. Tusks are often filed or etched with clan marks.

name: Darkblood Tiefling
nature_and_culture: Secretive, distrusted even among Tieflings; often drawn to shadowy guilds, mercenary bands, or solitary wandering. They balance paranoia with fierce independence.
combat: Quick, vicious fighters—favor ambush tactics, shadow magic, and poison.
spice: Darkblood Tieflings are said to carry whispers of their infernal ancestors in their dreams, and some claim their cracked skin glows faintly in moonlight.
appearance: Light-grey, cracked skin offsets black, jagged horns and a very long spiked tail. Hair is black or grey, eyes often a cool grey. They dress in shadow-dyed leathers and muted cloaks that conceal tools and blades, favoring movement and silence over ostentation.

name: Hellbound Tiefling
nature_and_culture: Proud, theatrical, leaning into their infernal legacy—many act as performers, warlocks, or leaders of dangerous cults.
combat: Fearless, aggressive; often frontline warriors or pyromancers.
spice: Rumored to smell faintly of brimstone when agitated, and their blood hisses when spilled on holy ground.
appearance: Rough red or orange skin, thick blunt horns of grey or light brown, and thick medium-length tails that match the body. Hair blazes in reds, oranges, or theatrical purples and pinks; eyes glow like embers. Their attire is dramatic—lacquered leathers, scaled coats, and flame motifs—made to be seen.

name: Voided Tiefling
nature_and_culture: Nihilistic, fatalistic; often philosophers or dangerous mages obsessed with entropy and forbidden knowledge.
combat: Cold precision; void magic, curses, and debilitating afflictions.
spice: Their shadows sometimes move independently of their bodies.
appearance: Pitch-black, smooth skin swallows light. Horns are long, straight, and glossy black; ears are very long and pointed. Hair is always light-toned against the void—white, silver, or pastel shades. Any iris may occur, but all eyes show black sclera. They favor minimalist, severe garments in matte blacks and quiet silvers.

name: Sableheart Tiefling
nature_and_culture: Seductive, charismatic; often thrive as merchants, diplomats, or spies. They are masters of intrigue.
combat: Subtle poisoners, fencers, illusionists.
spice: Their voices carry a strange, honeyed resonance that makes even insults sound alluring.
appearance: Light purple or light blue skin gleams with a silky gloss. Long curved horns shine like polished gold, silver, or bronze above luxurious pink or purple hair. Their attire is opulent—clingy silks, fitted leather corsetry, and jewelry that catches every candle flame.

name: Viridian Tiefling
nature_and_culture: Attuned to nature’s darker aspects; many become astrologers, alchemists, or druids. They’re often regarded as omens of strange change.
combat: Poison, herbs, astrology-based divination; use nature’s chaos as a weapon.
spice: Viridian Tieflings often bear faintly glowing star-maps tattooed or etched into their skin.
appearance: Light green or turquoise skin pairs with antler-like white or light-brown horns. Hair is brown or blonde; eyes tend to verdant greens. Tails are short and fur-tipped, matching the skin. Their garments weave leather with moss, feathers, and natural ornaments—half druidic, half aristocratic.

name: Halflings
nature_and_culture: Comfort, community, and cleverness; farmers, traders, storytellers—and thieves.
combat: Stealth, trickery, and ranged strikes; turn big foes’ strength against them.
spice: Seem to slip into crowds and shadows by luck alone.
appearance: Small and nimble with cheerful eyes, Halflings favor curly hair and bright, practical clothes—waistcoats, patched trousers, sturdy boots. Colors are warm and homely, with a fondness for pockets and snack-stashes.

name: Goblins
nature_and_culture: Scrap-savvy tinkerers thriving in chaos; ghettos and ramshackle tribes alike.
combat: Ambush swarms, traps, and unpredictable contraptions.
spice: Laughter that’s both infectious and terrifying.
appearance: Goblins tend toward green or gray skin, with sharp noses, pointed ears, and jagged smiles. Clothes are scavenged—stitched leather, bent buckles, and too many pockets—smelling faintly of oil and mischief.

name: Trollkin
nature_and_culture: Troll-blooded mercenaries and shamans walking the line between hunger and honor.
combat: Regenerative brutes who outlast foes; heavy axes and bone totems.
spice: Scars heal into ridges and patterns rather than fading.
appearance: Tall and heavy, Trollkin wear gray to green skin ridged with healed scars. Their garb is hide, bone, and iron—adorned with totems and trophies. A sour medicinal scent clings to their poultices and charms.

name: Sylvari
nature_and_culture: Symbiotic forest dwellers growing as much as building; druids and green wardens.
combat: Thorned arms, living vines, and nature magic; agile in woodland fights.
spice: Heartbeats slow as sap drip.
appearance: Sylvari wear bark-brown, leaf-green, or bloom-toned skin that shifts with seasons. Hair is moss, leaves, or flowerlike growths. Garments are grown rather than sewn—petal mantles, vine-wraps, and living bark cuirasses that flex like muscle.

name: Runeforged
nature_and_culture: Awakened husks seeking purpose and origin; rare and revered—or feared.
combat: Juggernauts with crushing blows; self-inscribed runes empower.
spice: Voices resonate like ringing anvils or grinding stone.
appearance: Runeforged bodies are wrought of stone, metal, or crystal etched with glowing runes. Taller than humans and heavy as anvils, they wear interlocking plates and rune-scribed tabards—armor and skin in one.

name: Myconids
nature_and_culture: Spore-communal circles in caverns and swamps; alien but deeply communal.
combat: Toxic/hallucinogenic spores, damp ambushes, and choking clouds.
spice: Nearby, one hears faint whispers on drifting spores.
appearance: Mushroom-capped and spongy, Myconids come in whites, purples, and reds. They wear fungus-grown capes and corded belts, shedding spores when startled; eyes glow faintly in the dark.

name: Kitsune
nature_and_culture: Playful tricksters and illusionists in hidden forest clans near mortal towns.
combat: Misdirection, illusions, and agile precision strikes.
spice: Tails shimmer under moonlight, fading during illusions.
appearance: Foxlike humanoids with keen, golden eyes and multiple sweeping tails. Hair runs red, white, black, or brown. They favor flowing robes, layered sashes, and masked hoods for festival or mischief; bells and charms hide in the folds.

name: Neko
nature_and_culture: Curious wanderers or city-dwellers; independent yet capable of deep bonds.
combat: Ambush and mobility specialists—leaps, claws, and quick blades.
spice: A soothing purr that calms even hardened warriors.
appearance: Cat-eared and tailed, Nekos move with feline grace. Their clothes lean to light leathers, cropped jackets, and fitted trousers for climbing and sprinting; bells and ribbons appear when they’re feeling playful.

name: Inugami
nature_and_culture: Pack-loyal oathkeepers honoring ancestors; fierce bonds of brotherhood.
combat: Frontline stamina fighters; wrathful when packmates fall.
spice: Always know the direction of “home,” however they define it.
appearance: Canine-featured humanoids with keen, loyal eyes. Inugami favor layered lamellar, padded jackets, and clan sashes; hair is often short or tied back for battle. Fetish cords and ancestor tags hang from belts and spears.

name: Lamia
nature_and_culture: Feared oracles of ruins and deserts; some monstrous, others wise hermits.
combat: Constriction, venom, and hypnotic gazes; lightning-fast strikes.
spice: Scale patterns shift subtly with mood—mesmerizing to stare at.
appearance: Serpent-bodied with vivid scales and a humanoid torso, Lamia wear jewelry, veils, and banded armlets that glitter against their coils. Hair tends to black or gold; eyes gleam like polished gems. Fabrics are airy and desert-bright, chosen for movement and allure.

name: Harpies
nature_and_culture: Cliff and peak nomads living in flocks; shrill songs both haunting and piercing.
combat: Aerial raiders diving and slashing before retreating; sonic disorientation.
spice: Songs stir emotions without magic—remnant of an ancient gift.
appearance: Harpies have feathered wings and taloned feet, with hair that mingles into plumage. They favor leather harnesses, wind-cut tunics, and feathered pauldrons that keep the arms free for flight and claws freed for the strike.

name: Minotaurs
nature_and_culture: Guardians and labyrinth-lore keepers; philosophers as often as wardens.
combat: Devastating charges and greataxe sweeps; mastery of confined-space combat.
spice: Never lost in a maze; some dream in winding paths.
appearance: Towering, bull-headed and broad, Minotaurs wear clan-carved horn rings and heavy harness leathers. Armored skirts and greaves leave hooves free; glyphs etched into horns mark ancestry and victories.

name: Satyrs
nature_and_culture: Revelers and grove-guardians—music, dance, and sacred rites in balance.
combat: Ambush, distraction, and song-woven magic with spears and bows.
spice: Pipes and flutes that stir courage or sleep like spells.
appearance: Goat-legged and bright-eyed, Satyrs wear wreaths, sashes, and open vests that leave room for revelry and dance. Short curling horns peek from hair; furred legs end in nimble hooves.

name: Cervans
nature_and_culture: Peaceful woodland clans that defend balance with sudden ferocity.
combat: Swift hunters with bows/spears; antlers formidable up close.
spice: Antlers glow faintly under moonlight, waxing and waning with it.
appearance: Deerfolk with branching antlers that elaborate with age, Cervans wear soft leather, bark plates, and cloaks mottled like the forest floor. Dappled markings trace shoulders and flanks; their steps are whisper-quiet.

name: Nagaji
nature_and_culture: Canny manipulators—advisors, merchants, or rulers by patience and persuasion.
combat: Polearms, venom blades, and charm/control magics; cold strategists.
spice: Tongues taste emotions, sensing fear or lies in the air.
appearance: Nagaji carry scaled skin in emeralds and golds with sleek black or gilded hair. Their clothing is layered silks over scaled cuirasses, jeweled collars masking a serpent’s smile; polearm tassels move like lures.

name: Arachne
nature_and_culture: Silk weavers and secret keepers in webbed caverns and cliff nests; revered or reviled.
combat: Ambushers who ensnare and strike from shadow; poisoned daggers in hand.
spice: Silk hums faintly with their thoughts and can channel magic.
appearance: Arachne possess human torsos fused to sleek spider bodies, with multifaceted or glowing eyes. They drape themselves in layered silk mantles and webbed harnesses, wearing blades as if part of the weave.

name: Caprines
nature_and_culture: Stubborn mountainfolk—herders, builders, and headstrong warriors.
combat: Horn charges, axes, and hammers; excel in brutal melee.
spice: Horns ring like bells when struck—ritual before battle.
appearance: Goatlike mountainfolk with stout frames and ringing horns, Caprines wear woolens, leather jerkins, and horn-guard helms. Beards are a point of pride, braided to display age and stubborn character.

name: Avianfolk
nature_and_culture: Cliff rookeries and sky shrines; omens and augury bind their castes: owl-seers, hawk-warriors, raven-messengers.
combat: Aerial skirmishers swooping with spears or talons; unrivaled scouts.
spice: Feathers shift hue with mood—silent chromatic speech.
appearance: Feathered humanoids with taloned feet and sweeping wings, Avianfolk wear leather harnesses, feathered capes, and sky-bright sashes that won’t snag in flight. Faces range from beaked to sharp-boned and masked.

name: Ursans
nature_and_culture: Northern shamans and guardians valuing patience and strength; tribal leaders and guides.
combat: Juggernauts with claws and mauls; weather blows others cannot.
spice: Dream-walkers who commune with great ancestral bears.
appearance: Bearfolk of immense build with thick fur in browns, blacks, or winter white. They wear heavy furs, bone charms, and leather harnesses marked with clan sigils; their presence is calm until roused.

name: Sharkkin
nature_and_culture: Ruthless tide-clans in coastal strongholds or roaming fleets; feared hunters and raiders.
combat: Harpoons, spears, and teeth; tireless, relentless close-range combat.
spice: Blood-scent frenzies heighten strength and speed in water.
appearance: Sleek and muscular with fins along limbs or back, Sharkkin move like water itself. They wear oilskin wraps, harness nets, and shell-plated vambraces; eyes are flat-black and intent.

name: Rodentia
nature_and_culture: City alleys and underground warrens; resourceful, communal, underestimated survivors.
combat: Swarming tactics, traps, and speed; daggers, slings, improvised arms.
spice: Given time, they chew through almost anything—even locks.
appearance: Small rodentfolk with twitching whiskers and long tails. They stitch waistcoats, scarves, and patchwork cloaks from cast-off fabrics—clever hands forever fidgeting with twine and gears.

name: Cervari
nature_and_culture: Endurance nomads of open plains; tireless traders and messengers.
combat: Rapid strike-and-withdraw skirmishers; refuse prolonged bog-downs.
spice: Can run for days without tiring.
appearance: Humanoids with subtle equine traits—long faces, horse-like ears, and powerful legs. They favor wind-cut coats, scarfed collars, and light brigandine that won’t tangle at speed; hair grows thick like a mane.

name: Centaurs
nature_and_culture: Restless herds roaming the plains; storytellers, poets, and warriors of the open sky.
combat: Mounted combat without mounts—lances, bows, trampling maneuvers.
spice: Never fully sleep; part of the mind keeps watch.
appearance: Half-human, half-horse, Centaurs blend human torsos with powerful equine bodies. Armor is leather-and-ring mail that flexes at the waist, with lance harnesses and tassels that mark herd and deeds.

name: Merfolk
nature_and_culture: Ocean cities and coastal kingdoms—singers, traders, and mystics.
combat: Tridents, nets, and water magic; supreme underwater agility.
spice: Songs travel miles through water, guiding or luring ships.
appearance: Merfolk bear scaled tails and gilled throats, with skin in sea-greens and blues. Hair flows like kelp and is adorned with shell combs and pearl strings. Armor is coral plate and fish-scale lamellar, with netted capes for ceremony.

name: Gnollkin
nature_and_culture: Savanna and wasteland pack-hunters; laughter joyous to kin, chilling to foes.
combat: Overwhelming raids with scavenged arms; bites as lethal as blades.
spice: Pre-battle laughter spreads contagiously through the pack.
appearance: Hyena-folk with spotted fur and a rangy, hungry grace. Their gear is scavenged mail, bone charms, and trophy cords; they grin too wide and laugh before the charge.

name: Porcans
nature_and_culture: Proud farmers and warriors of forests and hills; stubborn as stone.
combat: Relentless brawlers with axes and clubs; terrifying charges.
spice: Rage keeps them fighting long after wounds should fell them.
appearance: Boarfolk—stocky and bristled with jutting tusks. They favor strapped leathers, thick belts, and iron-studded bucklers; jaws are often pierced with rings that clack when they roar.

name: Mothfolk
nature_and_culture: Nocturnal mystics of moonlit glades; silk-and-pollen homes; peaceful yet uncanny.
combat: Illusions and wing powder to blind or pacify; gentle enchantments.
spice: Irresistibly drawn to flame; read omens in its flicker.
appearance: Ethereal humanoids with soft, patterned wings and furred antennae. Their garments are layered silks and pollen-dusted shawls; pale, powdered skin seems to glow under moonlight.

name: Jackalfolk (Anubari)
nature_and_culture: Desert wanderers and death-ritual priests; feared and revered psychopomps.
combat: Swift curved blades and short bows; speed and deception in dunes.
spice: Whisper prayers over every dead—friend or foe.
appearance: Lean and wiry with jackal heads and long ears, the Anubari wear desert linens, wrapped sashes, and gold-inlaid collars. Kohl-lined eyes stare unblinking in the sun; blades curve like dunes.

name: Owlkin
nature_and_culture: Silent nocturnal hunters and contemplative mystics; villages high in trees or on cliffs.
combat: Deadly silent ambushers with talons or bows; supreme night vision.
spice: Unblinking gaze that seems to read the soul.
appearance: Avian humanoids with large, expressive owl eyes and rounded feather-hoods. Their leathers are silent, their cloaks mottled like bark and shadow; talons are wrapped when not hunting.

name: Kobolds
nature_and_culture: Dragon-worshipping scavengers of warrens; dangerously inventive trapmakers.
combat: Cowardly alone, deadly en masse; ambushes, pitfalls, spear swarms.
spice: Can scent even a trace of dragon’s blood.
appearance: Small reptilian folk with scaly hides and bright eyes. They lash together scrap armor, riveted bucket-helms, and oversized spears, painting draconic sigils on everything that holds still.

name: Goliaths
nature_and_culture: Peak nomads who settle disputes with contests; survival and strength over pedigree.
combat: Massive weapons and iron endurance; shrug off fatigue and cold.
spice: Skin numbs to cold with altitude; some feel none at all.
appearance: Towering and broad, Goliaths wear stone-gray or slate-blue skin veined with dark markings. Their clothes are furs, heavy wraps, and strapped plates; tattoos recount climbs and challenges.

name: Tabaxi
nature_and_culture: Relic-chasers and story-hoarders; drift into cities as bards, rogues, scholars.
combat: Agile skirmishers—claws, bows, quick blades; speed over strength.
spice: Once curious, they must chase—prey, goals, or stories.
appearance: Jaguar- and leopard-folk with sleek spotted fur and brilliant eyes. They wear travel wraps, beadwork, and light armor—easy to climb in, easier to run.

name: Tortles
nature_and_culture: Patient wanderers and sea-road philosophers; homes carved into their shells.
combat: Durable defenders with clubs, staves, and tridents; outlast rather than overpower.
spice: Shells carved with their life journeys—living memoirs.
appearance: Tortles carry heavy shells inscribed with their histories. Skin is leathery and sea-toned; eyes placid. Their clothing is minimal—belts, satchels, and shell-carved harnesses—since the shell itself is both armor and home.

name: Kenku
nature_and_culture: Cursed mimics turned spies and thieves; perfect voices that isolate them.
combat: Stealth, knives, bows, and poisons; vanish into shadow after the strike.
spice: Mimicry so perfect it fools lovers and kin alike.
appearance: Crowlike humanoids cloaked in black feathers, with sharp beaks and deft claws. They dress in dark cloaks, wrap their feet for silence, and line their sleeves with hidden pockets for tools and trinkets.

name: Dragonborn
nature_and_culture: Honor-bound clans seeking lost draconic glory; martial, proud, and torn between worlds.
combat: Ferocious melee with breath weapons—fire, lightning, frost—making devastating shock troops.
spice: Anger brings a faint glow to their scales.
appearance: Tall draconic humanoids with vibrant scales and commanding presence. They wear scale harnesses, tabards bearing clan sigils, and heavy bracers; wings and tails are absent, but their stride leaves space for greatness.
